content.description: Fun little climb at the Playground.
content.location: Zig-zagging crack, first climb to the right of the most obvious climb on the cliff, an off-width corner.

climbs.name: The Sting
climbs.fa: Brad White, Barbara Knight, and Dick Peterson 1988

content.description: Start on a block and go up the vertical crack with the help of some good foot holds to a ledge at half height. Then up a v-groove feature to the top. Tree anchor off to the side or way back from the cliff top.
content.location: Find the short squeeze chimney  at the left end of the crag. This route is about 15 feet to the right of the chimney.

content.description: Twin hand cracks to groovy crux finish. Free soloed and rope climbed with Bill Hardigen in 1982. Bill with his long arms skipped the crux by reaching past it. Howard Peterson, Brad White, Babara Knight climbed it 1988 and called it Gemini.    I'll let the name remain the same but I'm not a Gemini. I'm an Aquarius, Hah!
content.protection: Trad rack with friends or hexes
content.location: Highest tier western wall. walk off left to trail

content.description: Climb the right-facing two-tiered corner on the rightmost side of the playground.
content.location: Right side of the playground, the obvious right-facing corner

content.description: Follow a finger crack in a shallow corner to a sloping ledge then up another finger crack through an overhang. A couple hard to see face holds help keep the second crux reasonable. This route is pretty hard for the guidebook grade of 5.9.
content.location: Just to the right of the route The Sting. Left end of the crag.

content.description: Climb the short vertical crack, following the path of least resistance. Starts at perfect hands and gets wider as you ascend.
content.protection: Standard Single Rack. Trees at top for anchor.
content.location: This route is on the far climber's left of The Playground.

content.description: Offwidth in the middle of the crag. Apparently 5.9 if you layback or 5.10b if you jam according to the guidebook. Jamming felt like the easier option to me.
Above the Zonkers wall is a collection of short routes including some good warmups.
